questions.question:
Question 1: Each muscle spindle consists of  
 intrafusal fibers.
questions.explanation:
• Each muscle spindle is 3 to 10 millimeters long. It is built around 3 to 12 tiny intrafusal muscle 
fibers that are attached to the glycocalyx of the surrounding large extrafusal skeletal muscle fibers. • Each intrafusal muscle fiber is a tiny skeletal muscle fiber. However, the central region of each of 
these fibers has few or no actin and myosin filaments. Therefore, this central portion does not 
contract when the ends do. Instead, it functions as a sensory receptor. The end portions that do 
contract are excited by small gamma motor nerve fibers.

questions.question: Question 2: Motor supply to muscle spindle is
questions.explanation:
Motor supply to muscle spindle is  Muscle spindles have a motor nerve supply of their own.These nerves belong to Erlanger and 
Gasser’s A■ group. They are just 3–6  in diameter (hence called small motor nerve system/■ 
efferents of Leksell) and go exclusively to muscle spindles. Note: • Motor innervation of muscle spindle is by gamma efferents • Motor innervation of extrafusal fibers is by alpha motor neurons Nuclear bag muscle fibers: 1–3 per muscle spindle. Nuclear chain muscle fibers: 3–9 per muscle spindle. 268 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 3: Identify the type of nerve fibre in the diagram below. 257 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
In the given figure, the fiber in yellow innervates the ends of the muscle spindle. Therefore, it is 
a gamma motor neuron. Many much smaller gamma motor neurons are located in the spinal cord anterior horns (shown 
as the yellow efferent fiber). These gamma motor neurons average 5 micrometers in diameter, 
which go to small, special skeletal muscle fibers called intrafusal fibers or the muscle spindle. 
These fibers constitute the ends of the muscle spindle, which help control basic muscle “tone.” Option (b): The alpha motor neurons (shown as the blue efferent fibre) are on an average 14 micrometers in 
diameter. These fibers branch many times after they enter the muscle and innervate the large 
skeletal muscle fibers at the motor endplate. Stimulation of a single alpha nerve fiber excites 269 
Sold by @itachibot anywhere from three to several hundred skeletal muscle fibers, which are collectively called the 
motor unit. Option (c): A-beta fibers are fibers for touch and pressure. Option (d): A-delta fibers are fibers for pain and temperature.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is false with respect to muscle spindles?

options.a: The intrafusal and extrafusal fibers are positioned paralled to each other
options.b: The primary endings of intrafusal fibers are most sensitive to a dynamic response
options.c: Type II nerve fibers do not innervate static nuclear bag fibers
options.d: Two types of  motor neurons supply the muscle spindle

questions.explanation:
Type II nerve fibers do innervate the static nuclear bag fibers. They do not innervate dynamic 
nuclear bag fibers. A muscle spindle has: • Intrafusal fibers - these are tiny skeletal muscles which have few or no actin and myosin 
filaments in the central portion. This portion acts as a sensory receptor. • Extrafusal fibers These fibers are positioned parallel to each other (Option A). There are two types of intrafusal fibers: • Nuclear bag fibers - subdivided as dynamic and static nuclear bag fibers • Nuclear chain fibers Sensory nerve supply: There are two types of sensory endings: • Primary endings - (annulospiral ending) from Type Ia nerve fibers. This innervates both the 
nuclear bag and nuclear chain fibers. They are most sensitive to the velocity of the change in 
muscle length. This is called a dynamic response. (Option B) 270 
Sold by @itachibot • Secondary endings - from Type II nerve fibers. This innervates static nuclear bag and nuclear 
chain fibers. They do not innervate dynamic nuclear bag fibers. (Option C) Both primary and secondary endings show a static response. Motor nerve supply: The muscle spindles are supplied by  motor neurons. There are two types 
of  motor neurons- dynamic that supply dynamic nuclear bag fibers and static that supply static 
nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers. (Option D)

questions.explanation:

questions.question: Question 6: The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate
questions.explanation:
The afferents for deep tendon reflexes innervate both - nuclear bag and chain fibers. The afferents for the DTRs are the type Ia and type II nerve fibers. There are three types of 
intrafusal muscle fibers: dynamic nuclear bag, static nuclear bag, and nuclear chain fibers. A 
single Ia afferent fiber innervates all three types of fibers to form a primary sensory ending. A 
group II sensory fiber innervates nuclear chain and static bag fibers to form a secondary sensory 
ending. Deep tendon reflexes are an example of stretch reflex or myotatic reflex.

questions.question: Question 7: Stimulus for stretch reflex is
questions.explanation: Stretch reflex occurs when the muscle is stretched passively. Stretch (myotatic) reflex is monosynaptic. (As illustrated in the figure given below, steps 15).

questions.question: Question 8: Withdrawal reflexes are not

options.b: Prolonged if the stimulus is strong
options.c: An example of a flexor reflex
options.d: Accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body

questions.explanation:
Withdrawal reflexes are not accompanied by the same response on both sides of the body. On the 
ipsilateral side of the pain stimulus, flexors are stimulated (they contract) and extensors are 
inhibited (they relax), and the arm is jerked away from the stove. On the contralateral side, flexors 
are inhibited and extensors are stimulated (crossed extension reflex) to maintain balance. It results in flexion on the ipsilateral side and extension on the contralateral side. Somatosensory and pain afferent fibers elicit withdrawal of the stimulated body part from the 
noxious stimulus. 272 
Sold by @itachibot Pain (e.g., touching a hot stove) stimulates the flexor reflex afferents of groups II, III, and IV. The afferent fibers synapse polysynaptically (via interneurons) onto motoneurons in the spinal 
cord. As a result of persistent neural activity in the polysynaptic circuits, an afterdischarge occurs. The 
afterdischarge prevents the muscle from relaxing for some time.

questions.question: Question 9: The maintenance of normal posture depends on
questions.explanation:
The maintenance of normal posture depends on the Integrity of reflex arc. The muscles that maintain upright posture—that is, support the body’s weight against 
gravity—are controlled by the brain and by reflex mechanisms. Three levels of the nervous system control movement: • The spinal cord, which integrates spinal reflexes and contains central pattern generators. • The brain stem and cerebellum, which control postural reflexes and hand and eye movements. • The cerebral cortex and basal ganglia, which are responsible for voluntary movements. 273 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 10: Receptor for inverse stretch reflex
questions.explanation:
Golgi tendon organ is the receptor for inverse stretch reflex (refer figure). The Golgi tendon organs, unlike the spindles, are in series with the muscle fibers; therefore, they 
are stimulated by both passive stretch and active contraction of the muscle. The degree of stimulation by contraction of muscles is much greater than that caused by the 
stretching of muscles. Muscle contraction  Ib fibers from the Golgi tendon organ excite an inhibitory interneuron that 
releases inhibitory mediator glycine  hyperpolarization (inhibition) of  motor neurons  
muscle relaxation. 274 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: The number of muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ is  
.
questions.explanation:
There are 3-20 muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ. • Golgi tendon organ consists of a netlike collection of knobby nerve endings among the fascicles 
of a tendon. • There are 3–25 muscle fibers per Golgi tendon organ. • The fibers from the Golgi tendon organs make up the Ib group of myelinated, rapidly conducting 
sensory nerve fibers. • Golgi tendon organs help in regulating the velocity of the muscle contraction, muscle length, and 
muscle force. • They are the receptor for inverse stretch reflex.

questions.question: Question 12: The inverse stretch reflex

options.a: Occurs when Ia spindle afferents are inhibited
options.b: Is a monosynaptic reflex initiated by activation of the Golgi tendon organ
options.c: Is a disynaptic reflex with a single interneuron inserted between the afferent and efferent limbs
options.d: Is a polysynaptic reflex with many interneurons inserted between the afferent and efferent

questions.explanation:
Golgi tendon reflex (Inverse myotatic/Inverse stretch reflex) is disynaptic, is the opposite, or 
inverse, of the stretch reflex. When tension on the muscle—and therefore on the tendon—becomes extreme, the inhibitory 
effect from the golgi tendon organ can be so great that it leads instantaneous relaxation of the 
entire muscle. This effect is called the lengthening reaction; it is probably a protective mechanism 
to prevent tearing of the muscle or avulsion of the tendon from its attachments to the bone. 275 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: All of the following are true about withdrawal reflex except

options.a: Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal are present
options.b: Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits are present
options.c: Circuits to cause afterdischarge that lasts many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over
options.d: The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex pass directly to the anterior motor

questions.explanation:
The pathways for eliciting the flexor withdrawal reflex do not pass directly to the anterior motor 
neurons; instead, they first pass into the spinal cord interneuron pool of neurons and only 
secondarily to the motor neurons. The shortest possible circuit is a three- or four-neuron pathway. 
The following basic types of circuits are present: • Diverging circuits to spread the reflex to the necessary muscles for withdrawal; • Circuits to inhibit the antagonist muscles, called reciprocal inhibition circuits; and • Circuits to cause after-discharge are present. They prolong the reflex contraction of the muscles 
that last many fractions of a second after the stimulus is over. 276 
Sold by @itachibot The flexor reflex is organized to withdraw a pained or otherwise irritated part of the body from a 
stimulus. Further, because of after-discharge, the reflex can hold the irritated part away from the 
stimulus for 0.1 to 3 seconds after the irritation is over. During this time, other reflexes and 
actions of the central nervous system can move the entire body away from the painful stimulus.

questions.question: Question 14: Muscle tone is maintained by
questions.explanation:
The resistance of a muscle to stretch is often referred to as its tone or tonus and muscle 
spindle helps to control basic muscle tone. The tonic (static) stretch reflex circuit includes both group Ia and group II afferent fibers from 
muscle spindles. Normally, there is ongoing activity in the Ia and II afferents that helps maintain 
a baseline firing of  motor neurons; therefore, the tonic stretch reflex contributes to muscle tone.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is true during initiation of voluntary movements?

options.a:   motor neurons are activated followed by  motor neuron
options.b:   motor neurons are activated followed by  motor neuron
options.c: Both  and ■ motor neurons are activated together

questions.explanation:
The cell bodies of  and  motor neurons to a given muscle lie close together. Both types are 
activated by interneurons in their immediate vicinity and sometimes directly by neurons of the 
descending pathways. During many voluntary and involuntary movements, they are coactivated, 
i.e., they are excited at almost the same time. ( -■ coactivation) The purpose of  -■ coactivation: • First, it keeps the length of the receptor portion of the muscle spindle from changing during the 
course of the whole muscle contraction. Hence, the muscle contraction is not opposed by the 
stretch reflex. • Second, if the muscle spindle did not contract and relax along with the large muscle fibers, the 
receptor portion of the spindle would sometimes be flail and sometimes be overstretched. Coactivation thus ensures that information about muscle length will be continuously available to 
provide for adjustment during ongoing actions and to plan and program future movements.

questions.question: Question 16: Righting reflex is
questions.explanation:
Righting reflexes operate to maintain the normal standing position and keep an animal's head 
upright. These reflexes are a series of responses integrated for the most part in the nuclei of the 
midbrain.

questions.question:
Question 17: In a patient with decerebrate rigidity, on applying pressure on the footpad, extension of that 
limb occurs. Which of the following statements is false regarding this phenomenon?

options.b: It is integrated at the Spinal Level
options.c: It helps to prevent falling on that side
options.d: It is a righting reflex integrated at midbrain level

questions.explanation:
Pressure on the footpad of a decerebrate patient causes the limb to extend against the pressure 
applied to the foot. This reflex is called the positive supportive reaction and is a righting reflex 
integrated at the spinal level. 277 
Sold by @itachibot Pressure on one side causes extension in that direction (e.g., on applying pressure on the right 
footpad, extension of the right lower limb occurs), an effect called the magnet reaction. It is seen 
in infants and following spinal transection. From an evolutionary perspective, this reflex helps to prevent falling on the side where the 
stimulus is given.

questions.question: Question 18: Pyramids are formed by
questions.explanation:
The corticospinal pathways are also called the pyramidal tracts or pyramidal system because of 
their triangular shape as they pass along the ventral surface of the medulla oblongata.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is true about corticospinal tract?
questions.explanation:
The corticospinal tract contains crossed fibers (majority). Fibers of the corticospinal tract originate from the primary motor cortex (about 30%), the 
premotor and supplementary motor areas (30%), and the somatosensory areas posterior to the 
central sulcus (40%). Most fibers (80% fibers) decussate (cross) in the medullary pyramids and descend in the lateral 
white matter of the spinal cord to form the lateral corticospinal tract. They control the movements 
of the contralateral limbs. The remaining 20% make up the ventral corticospinal tract. These fibers remain uncrossed until 
reaching the spinal cord where axons terminate bilaterally on spinal interneurons antecedent to 
motor neurons. These fibers control the movements of the axial musculature. 278 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following is false regarding the origin of corticospinal tract?

options.a: Corticospinal tract fibers originate from Betz Cells
options.b: 30% from premotor and supplementary motor areas

questions.explanation:
30% of corticospinal tract originates about from the primary motor cortex, not 90%. 30 % from the premotor and supplementary motor areas. 40 % from the somatosensory areas 
posterior to the central sulcus. Betz cells • Some large myelinated fibres in the corticospinal tract originate from giant pyramidal cells, also 
known as Betz cells. • Found in the layer 5 of primary motor cortex. • These large fibers represent only 3 percent of the total fibers of the corticospinal tract. (The 
other 97 percent less than 4 micrometers in diameter that conduct background tonic signals to the 
motor areas of the cord.) 279 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 21: Which of the following is not an extrapyramidal tract?
questions.explanation: Corticospinal tract is a pyramidal tract . Pyramidal tracts (corticospinal and corticobulbar) pass through the medullary pyramids. All others are extrapyramidal tracts and originate primarily in the the brain stem.

questions.question: Question 22: Which pathway is not involved in maintainence of posture?
questions.explanation:
Rubrospinal tract is not involved in posture maintenance. Medial motor system • Controls the axial muscles (muscles of the trunk) • Axial muscles are concerned with postural adjustments and gross movements Lateral motor system • Controls the distal muscles • Distal muscles mediate fine, skilled movements 280 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 23: Gamma motor neurons are mainly influenced by
questions.explanation:
• The pontine and medullary reticulospinal tracts are involved in maintainance of posture and in 
modulating muscle tone especially via an input to ■- motor neurons. • Pontine reticulospinal neurons are primarily excitatory and medullary reticulospinal neurons are 
primarily inhibitory. • Stimulation of -motor neurons does not lead directly to detectable contraction of the muscles 
because the intrafusal fibers are not strong enough or plentiful enough to cause shortening. • However, stimulation does cause the contractile ends of the intrafusal fibers to shorten and 
therefore stretches the nuclear bag portion of the spindles, deforming the endings, and initiating 
impulses in the Ia fibers . This in turn can lead to reflex contraction of the muscle. • Thus, muscles can be made to contract via stimulation of the  -motor neurons that innervate the 
extrafusal fibers or the -motor neurons that initiate contraction indirectly via the stretch reflex.

questions.question: Question 24: According to Herrington classification, the decerebrate rigidity is characterized by all except

options.a: Rigidity occurs in all the muscles of the body
options.b: Increase in the rate of discharge of the ■ efferent neuron
options.c: Increased excitability of the motor neuron pool
options.d: Decerebration produces no phenomenon akin to spinal shock

questions.explanation:
In decerebrate rigidity, there is rigidity in extensor muscles of all the four extremities (not all 
muscles of the body). Decerebration • Complete transection of the brain stem between the superior and inferior colliculi permits the 
brain stem pathways to function independently of their input from higher brain structures. This is 
called a mid-collicular decerebration. • This lesion interrupts all input from the cortex (corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts) and red 
nucleus (rubrospinal tract), primarily to distal muscles of the extremities. 281 
Sold by @itachibot • The excitatory and inhibitory reticulospinal pathways (primarily to postural extensor muscles) 
remain intact. • The dominance of drive from ascending sensory pathways to the excitatory reticulospinal 
pathway leads to hyperactivity in extensor muscles in all four extremities which are called 
decerebrate rigidity. • The excitatory input from the reticulospinal pathway activates -motor neurons which indirectly 
activate  -motor neurons (via Ia spindle afferent activity). This is called the gamma loop. Option 4. Spinal shock is different from decebrate rigidity as it is a transient state that can occur 
immediately after a spinal cord injury. It is characterized by a temporary loss or depression of 
spinal reflexes below the level of the injury.

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following is true for decorticate rigidity?

options.a: It is produced by the removal of cerebral cortex and basal ganglia
options.b: Flexion of lower limbs and extension of upper limbs occurs
options.d: It is characterized by flexion of upper limbs and extension of lower limbs

questions.explanation:
• Removal of the cerebral cortex (decortication) produces decorticate rigidity. • Characterized by flexion of the upper extremities at the elbow and extensor hyperactivity in the 
lower extremities. • The flexion can be explained by active rubrospinal excitation of flexor muscles in the upper 
extremities; the hyperextension of lower extremities is due to the same changes that occur after 
midcollicular decerebration.

questions.question: Question 26: Which of the following reflex is absent in a decorticate animal?
questions.explanation:
The Hopping and Placing reflex is absent in a decorticate animal as it is integrated in the cerebral 
cortex. Rest of the reflexes are integrated below the cortex. 282 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 27: Destruction of anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to  
.

options.c: Increased rigidity via alpha motor neuron

questions.explanation:
Destruction of the anterior cerebellum in a decerebrate animal leads to an increased rigidity via 
alpha motor neuron. If the anterior lobe of the cerebellum is removed in a decerebrate animal, extensor muscle 
hyperactivity is exaggerated (decerebellate rigidity). This cut eliminates cortical inhibition of the 
cerebellar fastigial nucleus and secondarily increases excitation to vestibular nuclei. Subsequent 
dorsal root section does not reverse the rigidity, hence proving that the rigidity is due to activation 
of  -motor neurons independent of the gamma loop.

questions.question: Question 28: Upper Motor Neurons (UMN) include
questions.explanation:
• Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor 
neurons, but they can also include brainstem neurons that control spinal motor neurons. • Corticospinal tract contain a population of large myelinated fibers with a mean diameter of 16 
micrometers. These fibers originate from giant pyramidal cells, called Betz cells, that are found 
only in the primary motor cortex.

questions.question:
Question 29: A 30-year-old man meets with an accident and develops spinal cord transection. Which of the 
following features will be seen as a result of pyramidal tract injury below the level of motor 
decussation?
questions.explanation:
Cutting the pyramidal tract below the decussation (UMN lesion) causes abnormal plantar extensor 
reflex (positive Babinski sign). It initially causes muscles to become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, 
hypertonia (increased resistance to passive movement), and hyperactive stretch reflexes. The image below shows the pyramidal tract (corticospinal pathway). 283 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 30: A 36-year-old male patient presented to the ER following a road traffic accident. Which of the 
following features would not be present if there is a corticospinal tract involvement?
questions.explanation:
Cog-wheel rigidity is not seen if there is a corticospinal tract involvement. Cogwheel rigidity is 
seen in extrapyramidal tract involvement when there is a tremor superimposed on hypertonia 
(e.g., Parkinsonism). In an upper motor neuron lesion, there is damage to the corticospinal or corticobulbar fibres. If 
the corticospinal fibres are damaged, it leads to diminished or loss of superficial reflexes, shows 
an extensor plantar response (Babinski's sign) with loss of fine skilled movement and spasticity.

questions.question:
Question 31: While exercising, a 42-year-old woman developed sudden onset of tingling in her right leg 
and an inability to control movement in that limb. A neurologic exam showed a hyperactive 264 
Sold by @itachibot knee jerk reflex and a positive Babinski sign. Which of the following is not true regarding her 
condition?

options.a: Reflexes can be modified by impulses from various parts of the CNS
options.b: Reflexes may involve simultaneous contraction of some muscles and relaxation of others
options.c: Reflexes are chronically suppressed after spinal cord transection
options.d: Reflexes often occur without conscious perception

questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal cord transection, which is characterized by an 
exaggeration of reflexes and not suppression. Upper motor neurons typically refer to corticospinal tract neurons that innervate spinal motor 
neurons. Damage to these neurons, as in transection of the spinal cord, initially causes muscles to 
become weak and flaccid but eventually leads to spasticity, hypertonia (increased resistance to 
passive movement), hyperactive reflexes, and abnormal plantar extensor reflex (positive Babinski 
sign).

questions.question:
Question 32: A 50-year-old man with a history of medically controlled atrial fibrillation develops sudden 
onset weakness in the right side of his body. Which of the following Broadman's area is most 
likely affected?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of an acute stroke, most probably due to atrial fibrillation 
induced thromboembolism. Since the patient has developed motor weakness in the right side of 
his body, he most likely has an infarct affecting the primary motor cortex ( broadmann area 4). • The primary motor cortex (or just the motor cortex) can be defined as the region of the cortex 
from which movements are elicited with the least amount of electrical stimulation. • It is essentially congruent with Brodmann's cytoarchitectonic area 4. • The primary motor cortex (M1) is in the precentral gyrus of the frontal lobe, extending into the 
central sulcus. 284 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 33: Skilled voluntary movement is initiated by
questions.explanation:
Commands for voluntary movements originate in cortical association areas. The corticospinal and corticobulbar system (originating in the motor cortex located in precentral 
gyrus) is the primary pathway for the initiation of skilled voluntary movement. The movements are planned in the cortex as well as in the basal ganglia and the lateral portions of 
the cerebellar hemispheres. The basal ganglia and cerebellum funnel information to the premotor and motor cortex by way of 
the thalamus. Motor commands from the motor cortex are relayed in large part via the corticospinal tracts to the 
spinal cord. 285 
Sold by @itachibot Movement sets up alterations in sensory input from the special senses and from muscles, tendons, 
joints, and the skin. This feedback information, which adjusts and smooths movement, is relayed 
directly to the motor cortex and to the spinocerebellum.

questions.question: Question 34: In the homunculus, which of the following has maximum representation?
questions.explanation:
In a homunculus, the more the representation of an area, the more precise the movements are. • The relative sizes of the cortical receiving areas of the sensory homunculus are proportionate to 
the use of the part. • The sizes of these areas are directly proportional to the number of specialized sensory 
receptors in each respective peripheral area of the body. • Some body parts are represented by large areas in the somatic cortex—the lips the greatest of all, 
followed by the face and thumb, whereas the trunk and lower part of the body are represented by 
relatively small areas. 286 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 35: In the degrees of representation of the different muscle areas as mapped by Penfield and 
Rasmussen in the primary motor cortex, which of the following has the maximum 
representation?
questions.explanation:
As seen from the figure given below, Vocalization > Salivation > Mastication > Thumb The topographical organization is demonstrated graphically in the figure, which shows the degrees 
of representation of the different muscle areas as mapped by Penfield and Rasmussen. This 
mapping was done by electrically stimulating the different areas of the motor cortex in human 
beings who were undergoing neurosurgical operations. The face is represented bilaterally. The rest of the body has a unilateral representation.

questions.question:
Question 36: While doing a neurosurgical procedure, the paracentral lobules of both hemispheres were 
damaged. It will lead to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
287 
Sold by @itachibot Damage to both paracentral lobules will cause paraplegia. The paracentral lobule is the medial continuation of the precentral and postcentral gyri. It 
controls motor and sensory innervations of the contralateral lower extremity. It is also responsible 
for the control of defecation and urination.

questions.question:
Question 37: Setting posture before planned movement is associated with  
.
questions.explanation:
• The premotor cortex may be concerned with a setting posture at the start of a planned 
movement and getting the individual prepared to move. It is most involved in control of proximal 
limb muscles needed to orient the body for movement. • It is located anterior to the precentral gyrus, on the lateral and medial cortical surface; it also 
contains a somatotopic map almost identical to the topographic organization in primary motor 
cortex with the mouth and face areas located most laterally. As one moves upward, the hand, arm, 
trunk, and leg areas are encountered. (as seen in the figure below) • This region receives input from sensory regions of the parietal cortex and projects to primary 
motor cortex (M1), the spinal cord, and the brainstem reticular formation. • A special class of neurons called mirror neurons becomes active when a person performs a 
specific motor task or when he or she observes the same task performed by others. These neurons 
transform sensory representations of acts that are heard or seen into motor representations of 
these acts.

questions.question:
Question 38: A quadriplegic man with a high cervical lesion develops sudden onset of flushing, sweating, 
pounding headache and hypertension. He has a distended bladder due to a blocked urinary 
catheter. On immediate drainage of the urinary bladder and repositioning him from supine to 
reclining, his symptoms resolve. Which of the following is false regarding the most likely 
diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of spinal mass reflex which is seen in patients with a high 
spinal lesion. A major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasm, and 
not extensor spasm, in a spinal mass reflex. 288 
Sold by @itachibot Mass Reflex: In a spinal animal or human being, sometimes the spinal cord suddenly becomes 
excessively active, causing massive discharge in large portions of the cord. The usual stimulus that 
causes this excess activity is a strong pain stimulus to the skin or excessive filling of a viscus, such 
as over-distention of the bladder or the gut. The mass reflex involves large portions or even all of 
the cord. The effects are as follows: • A major portion of the body’s skeletal muscles goes into strong flexor spasms; • The colon and bladder are likely to evacuate; • The arterial pressure often rises to maximal values, sometimes to a systolic pressure well over 
200 mm Hg; and • Large areas of the body break out into profuse sweating. The mechanism is similar to the mechanism of epileptic seizures, which involve reverberating 
circuits that occur in the brain instead of in the cord. 289 
Sold by @itachibot Motor Physiology - 2
